notes.text:
An update for thunderbird is now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8.6 Extended Update Support.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Important. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability from the CVE link(s) in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
Mozilla Thunderbird is a standalone mail and newsgroup client.

This update upgrades Thunderbird to version 102.5.0.

Security Fix(es):

* Mozilla: Service Workers might have learned size of cross-origin media files (CVE-2022-45403)

* Mozilla: Fullscreen notification bypass (CVE-2022-45404)

* Mozilla: Use-after-free in InputStream implementation (CVE-2022-45405)

* Mozilla: Use-after-free of a JavaScript Realm (CVE-2022-45406)

* Mozilla: Fullscreen notification bypass via windowName (CVE-2022-45408)

* Mozilla: Use-after-free in Garbage Collection (CVE-2022-45409)

* Mozilla: Memory safety bugs fixed in Firefox 107 and Firefox ESR 102.5 (CVE-2022-45421)

* Mozilla: ServiceWorker-intercepted requests bypassed SameSite cookie policy (CVE-2022-45410)

* Mozilla: Cross-Site Tracing was possible via non-standard override headers (CVE-2022-45411)

* Mozilla: Symlinks may resolve to partially uninitialized buffers (CVE-2022-45412)

* Mozilla: Keystroke Side-Channel Leakage (CVE-2022-45416)

* Mozilla: Custom mouse cursor could have been drawn over browser UI (CVE-2022-45418)

* Mozilla: Iframe contents could be rendered outside the iframe (CVE-2022-45420)

For more details about the security issue(s), including the impact, a CVSS score, acknowledgments, and other related information, refer to the CVE page(s) listed in the References section.
notes.title: Details

names: Anne van Kesteren and Karl Tomlinson

cwe.name: Inclusion of Functionality from Untrusted Control Sphere

notes.text: The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as: Service Workers should not be able to infer information about opaque cross-origin responses; but timing information for cross-origin media combined with Range requests might have allowed them to determine the presence or length of a media file.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: Mozilla: Service Workers might have learned size of cross-origin media files
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

All running instances of Thunderbird must be restarted for the update to take effect.

vulnerabilities.title: Mozilla: Service Workers might have learned size of cross-origin media files

cwe.name: Improper Restriction of Rendered UI Layers or Frames

notes.text: The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as: Through a series of popup and window.print() calls, an attacker can cause a window to go fullscreen without the user seeing the notification prompt, resulting in potential user confusion or spoofing attacks.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: Mozilla: Fullscreen notification bypass
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.

All running instances of Thunderbird must be restarted for the update to take effect.

notes.text: The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as: Freeing arbitrary nsIInputStream's on a different thread than creation could have led to a use-after-free and potentially exploitable crash.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: Mozilla: Use-after-free in InputStream implementation

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.

notes.text:
The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as:

If an out-of-memory condition occurred when creating a JavaScript global, a JavaScript realm may be deleted while references to it lived on in a BaseShape. This could lead to a use-after-free causing a potentially exploitable crash.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: Mozilla: Use-after-free of a JavaScript Realm
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: Red Hat Product Security rates the severity of this flaw as determined by the Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.

notes.text: The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as: Through a series of popups that reuse windowName, an attacker can cause a window to go fullscreen without the user seeing the notification prompt, resulting in potential user confusion or spoofing attacks.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: Mozilla: Fullscreen notification bypass via windowName

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.

vulnerabilities.title: Mozilla: Fullscreen notification bypass via windowName

notes.text: The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as: The garbage collector could have been aborted in several states and zones and GCRuntime::finishCollection may not have been called, leading to a use-after-free and potentially exploitable crash.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: Mozilla: Use-after-free in Garbage Collection
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

All running instances of Thunderbird must be restarted for the update to take effect.

cwe.name: Sensitive Cookie with Improper SameSite Attribute

notes.text: The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as: When a ServiceWorker intercepted a request with FetchEvent, the origin of the request was lost after the ServiceWorker took ownership of it. This had the effect of negating SameSite cookie protections. This was addressed in the spec and then in browsers.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: Mozilla: ServiceWorker-intercepted requests bypassed SameSite cookie policy
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

All running instances of Thunderbird must be restarted for the update to take effect.

vulnerabilities.title: Mozilla: ServiceWorker-intercepted requests bypassed SameSite cookie policy

cwe.name: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting')

notes.text: The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as: Cross-Site Tracing occurs when a server will echo a request back via the Trace method, allowing an XSS attack to access to authorization headers and cookies inaccessible to JavaScript (such as cookies protected by HTTPOnly). To mitigate this attack, browsers placed limits on fetch() and XMLHttpRequest; however some webservers have implemented non-standard headers such as X-Http-Method-Override that override the HTTP method, and made this attack possible again. Firefox has applied the same mitigations to the use of this and similar headers.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: Mozilla: Cross-Site Tracing was possible via non-standard override headers
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

All running instances of Thunderbird must be restarted for the update to take effect.

vulnerabilities.title: Mozilla: Cross-Site Tracing was possible via non-standard override headers

cwe.name: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor

notes.text:
The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as:

When resolving a symlink such as file:///proc/self/fd/1, an error message may be produced where the symlink was resolved to a string containing unitialized memory in the buffer.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: Mozilla: Symlinks may resolve to partially uninitialized buffers
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: Red Hat Product Security rates the severity of this flaw as determined by the Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory.
notes.title: Statement

vulnerabilities.title: Mozilla: Symlinks may resolve to partially uninitialized buffers

notes.text: The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as: Keyboard events reference strings like "KeyA" that were at fixed, known, and widely-spread addresses. Cache-based timing attacks such as Prime+Probe could have possibly figured out which keys were being pressed.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: Mozilla: Keystroke Side-Channel Leakage
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.

notes.text: The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as: If a custom mouse cursor is specified in CSS, under certain circumstances the cursor could have been drawn over the browser UI, resulting in potential user confusion or spoofing attacks.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

names: Suhwan Song of SNU CompSec Lab

notes.text: The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as: Use tables inside of an iframe, an attacker could have caused iframe contents to be rendered outside the boundaries of the iframe, resulting in potential user confusion or spoofing attacks.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

cwe.name: Buffer Copy without Checking Size of Input ('Classic Buffer Overflow')

notes.text: The Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory describes this flaw as: Mozilla developers Andrew McCreight and Gabriele Svelto reported memory safety bugs present in Firefox 106 and Firefox ESR 102.4. Some of these bugs showed evidence of memory corruption and we presume that with enough effort some of these could have been exploited to run arbitrary code.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: Mozilla: Memory safety bugs fixed in Firefox 107 and Firefox ESR 102.5
